content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The problem is of a suitable length for CoC, and the test cases are quite interesting

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is a fun and easy (in my opinion) CoC, that is good at introducing the idea of run length encoding to new coders.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice pictures :)
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

I like the final comparison.
I read below that it feels a bit wordy, and I can agree.
Here is my attempt to compress ;) the intro:

The run-length encoding (RLE) is a form of lossless data compression in which runs of data are stored as a single data value and count, between delimiters.

A black and white image, represented by a grid of 0 and 1, could be compressed as a succession of /quantity/color/ blocks.

The goal is to print the RLE encoded image followed by the compression ratio in % (and display if it's bad)

I hope to play it soon!

I like this challenge a lot, but I think that there shouldn't be a delimiter, rather a standard size for X, padded with 0's when necessary.
Also if the input is in binary 1's and 0's, then the output should reflect that to create a more accurate portrayal of how much its compressing. That will also generate a more accurate compression ratio.
Keep up the good work!
May be too long for a CoC, at least for me
Very nice. It is a bit challenging for a clash of code, but why not.

C'est vraiment super chouette ! Par contre je le trouve un peu dur pour un CoC de 15 minutes... 
Je pense que si tu le complexifie, avec, par exemple, un système d'encodage qui utilise la similarité de lignes, ça pourrait faire un excellent puzzle !!


It's really great! But I find it a bit hard for a 15 minutes CoC... 
I think that if you make it more complex, with, for example, an encoding system that uses line similarity, it could make a great puzzle!


Bravo, Congrats !!

For black and white images there is not need to give the values as we know they alternate. And we can start with X=0 if the first color is not the start color.

But this is a detail not needed for a clash.
The width on line 2 of input is not needed (it would be in a real case but it would also be in the output).

Was fun :) I cheated with groupby from itertools in Python.

from itertools import groupby

n = int(input())
w = int(input())
image = ''.join(input() for _ in range(n))

encoded = ''.join(f'/{len(list(g))}/{k}' for k,g in groupby(image))
print(encoded)
print(f'{len(encoded)/len(image):.0%}' + (' bad ratio' if len(encoded)> len(image) else ''))

Very unique problem, would love to see this in an actual clash. I think the 2nd bullet point is a bit too wordy to the point of being confusing. You're describing the steps to turn a ratio into a percent, without just outright stating that you want it in percentage form. I would just use "expressed in the form of a percentage" in the bullet point, and then make an additional bullet point describing how to do that. For the 2nd bullet point I might use "The compression ratio is the number of characters in the encoded string (including delimiters, excluding end of lines) over the input image size, expressed in the form of a percentage, rounded to the nearest integer." and for the extra bullet point I might write "To express a ratio as a percentage, you divide the 1st number by the 2nd number, multiply by 100, then add a % sign to the end."

The description is good and complete, maybe it can be presented more succinctly, maybe some of the 'Output' paragraph can be moved to the 'Goal' paragraph.

So, adding to 'goal' that the goal is to print the compressed image followed by the compression ratio and to check whether the ratio is bad.
Then you can add the specifics for calculating ratio in a list instead of in a running paragraph.

The 'Goal' paragraph will be less cluttered.


The whole assignment was fun to do! and quite easy. here is a solution using regex in python:

```compressed = re.sub('0+|1+',lambda x:f'/{len(x[0])}/{x[0][0]}', line)```
This is my first contribution. I hope you will like it.
Thanks for the detailed feedback. I've just updated the statement and I hope it looks better. I will also try to make it shorter if I can.
I will change it today. Thanks for the suggestion.

I agree it is not absolutely needed but in case we want to decompress the compressed images (may be my future proposal), the width will be needed. This is to remain realistic. ;-)
(I just noticed my comment is exactly what you meant :-)  )
Yep, true. But for the clash, I'll leave it like that.

Do you think the time issue is with the time it took you to fully understand the statement or more with the time it took you to code it?
I will try it again and time myself to check.

Could you explain the reason for a standart size for X instead of a delimiter? I think they are almost equivalent.
Regarding your second remark, as this is for a CoC, I wanted to make it simple. But of course we could derive a puzzle on image compression (or decompression) with more details and closer to a real life implementation.
Thanks for your comment. However, I decided not to change the statement because, I don't find it easier to understand even though it is much shorter.
Thanks ;-)
Thanks
Thanks

To elaborate on a standard size for X, I meant how many bits in size it can be. For example 2 in a standard byte is 0000 0010. That would eliminate the need for a delimiter before and after the run length, which gets to be inefficient for alternating bits, i.e. 1010 -> /1/1 /1/0 /1/1 /1/0.
Of course, you're right about keeping it simple for a CoC. What you've made is good at demonstrating the implementation of run length encoding..

I see better your point. I knew introducing a delimiter would be inefficient. However, it makes the CoC a little easier to solve, I think, and some people already complained they've found it a bit too hard. So I'll leave it as it is except if a lot of people want me to change it. ;-)
I had no problem understanding the statement. I said that for me it was too long as I'm using CG to train in python and I don't have enough coding automatism in this language yet.
Could you please upvote my proposal if you liked it? Thanks
It may be a good idea to suppress the W parameter as you've suggested. I need to think about it...

In the final (I hope) version, I've removed the W because as you pointed out, it is not needed. I've adapted the statement, the tests, the stub and the solution. Thanks again for carefully having a look.

I changed it. I hope it is less confusing now, but I can change it again if needed. ;-) I've put the explanation about how to compute a percentage between parenthesis because most of us will not need it.
